btw in terms of getting past keyword filters, and the technical interviewer being willing to overlook some mismatch in those keywords as long as you demonstrate a readiness to learn tools as needed, the same generally applies to a lot of things. at a beginner level, learning a whole new language may be a big obstacle, but after mastery of basic programming and some real world dev experience, it's generally considered not a huge deal to learn a new language or framework, and you can approach job hunting accordingly. most jobs will want you to already have the core technical skills involved but the rest may often be optional, things you can learn on the job as part of the onboarding process.

I posted a quick thing this on Twitter, but I figure a few other folks might be interested in seeing this here as well. So we’re currently working on a game that makes extensive use of full motion video. Specifically, green-screened puppets.

As part of the game we wanted to layer some interaction on top of the video, which requires some kind of tracking the position of in-video objects and translating that position into Unity’s world space. We’re a team of 2 dealing with potentially hours of video, so I had to develop a fully automated process for doing so. Normally in special FX work, there’s a partially automated process using trackers that then gets cleaned up with manual rotoscoping if needed.

I started out by finding general object tracking tutorials and found this one here (<https://www.pyimagesearch.com/2015/09/14/ball-tracking-with-opencv/>). This gave me most of the base code I needed, and the next step was just to tweak the color range and tracking to the source video I was working with. In our case, we were already using green for the background, so our tracking object was blue. Once I had that down, I exported the position data with timestamps to a binary file and set up the the corresponding read and position code in unity to align the positions with the video rendered in Unity. Here’s what it looks like on the opencv side:

_*Dynamic, growing machine learning software company seeks curious, talented, and passionate AI/ML algorithm developers and data analysts.*_

*Who’s CoVar?*

We are a small band of researchers, engineers, and software developers who love what we do and are looking for others to join us. We are at the cutting edge of machine learning and computer vision and constantly striving to understand more and do more. We conduct research and develop software products for many different customers. Some of our customers look to us to find bad guys and bad things in military sensor data—helping to keep our nation and our servicemembers safe. Other customers need help finding new cures for diseases hidden across existing biomedical databases—saving the lives of those stricken with rare diseases. Other customers use our products to monitor machinery and workers in the energy sector, preventing injuries and environmental catastrophes. We stop bad stuff from happening.

*What is it like to work with us?*

Every one of us is absolutely passionate about what we do, and this passion is infectious. We love to debate new ideas on their merits—our white boards are constantly in use. We love to see if our ideas will work and are constantly experimenting, prototyping, and tweaking. We enjoy working on a variety of projects—which makes it fun to have many customers with varied problems. Some of our work is heady research, some is fast-paced product development. The most interesting projects are both.

*Who are we looking for?*

We’d like to grow our team with research engineers/algorithm developers who are:
·       Passionate and proficient in some subset of machine learning, computer vision, natural language processing, image processing, signal processing, Bayesian inference 
·       Take a hands-on and statistically-sound approach to solving problems
·       Curious about the underlying domain physics of a problem space 
·       Excellent at communicating these concepts to our customers

We are hiring for our Durham, NC location and are looking for folks who are eligible for security clearances.

*What Do We Offer?*
·       Competitive salary, cash bonus, and equity structure 
·       401k with employer contributions 
·       Excellent health care coverage, including dental and vision plans 
·       Flexible work schedule 
·       Rewarding, varied, and intellectually stimulating work 
·       Non-hierarchical and inclusive environment 
·       Opportunity to learn and grow as an engineer—wherever you are in your career
·       Re-location expenses

Email us: <mailto:careers@covar.com|careers@covar.com>
Visit us: <http://www.covar.com|www.covar.com>

I second what <@U8SFYQ3NZ> describes. My previous gig we had PMs focused on few areas (not components, but say business-related themes) and component/feature teams managed by POs. We ended up having limited resources (cross-team tech dependencies are :skull:), so had very limited resources. eventually ended up being VP PM, then two PMs (me and a colleague, who focused on onboarding/developer's journey) combined with POs, who we made the owners of roadmap (not strategy though!), and that required them to interface more frequently with customers and be the ones responsible for prioritization (not PM, who focused on setting the context/strategy with business peers). am trying to set up something similar at my new gig (very lean, small teams).

Another way to look at is what types of products are you supporting and how big are those products. I've seen the PM/PO combined role in most organizations, but that's been doable because they've had relatively small scrum teams supporting them. Once you hit a certain capacity with engineering, there are only so many requirements one person can create every sprint. And once you layer in the need for strategy/research/planning on the PM side, you can see that it comes down to how much can one person do.

## What are some blockers with learning how to think in abstractions with code? Do people who take things literally have more problems with this than others?

Honestly, it's just an experience thing. The opposite can be a problem (being unable to think literally), but comfort with abstractions comes from following certain steps long enough and giving a name to the pattern.

## Talk more about topic ghettos

Topic ghettos are when you group up a bunch of related things and teach them at the same time, but independently from how they're actually applied. In other words, teaching a gaggle of math concepts together is tidy, but if each of the math concepts are applied in wildly different ways it's difficult to create relevance with them.

## How is coding is different than other kinds of skills?

It isn't. It has more in common with throwing a football, meditating, or dancing than it doesn't. A difference might be that it can be used to leverage so many other skills that it makes _them_ more valuable in the process, but it's acquired and developed in the same way.

## Whats the best advice you'd give developers on searching for the right job? (Particularly when it's the 1st job out of school)?

Network. Cold applications to job postings are fine and should be in your rotation too, but you have a much better chance going through someone you've met, in-person or virtually. In order of preference, companies generally hire for roles:

1. Internally ("We moved Sarah into that role")
2. Internal referral ("Sarah recommended someone")
3. External referral ("Sarah knows someone who recommended someone")

## Thoughts on the Lambda School scandal?

They are a garbage school run by Silicon Valley children, and they deserve the criticism they're getting. That said, a lot of the people criticizing them _also_ don't know shit about education and some of their critiques are completely invalid. For example, hiring your students isn't some cost savings measure or a way to pad the numbers. Even in Lambda's case, if every one of their 170 employees was a _currently enrolled_ student it would juice their garbo placement numbers _for only that class_ about 5%. People who recently learned something are a treasure in a classroom. Also "teacher" is one of the most common jobs in America. The chances of finding a dev who can teach their way out of a paper bag is pretty hard; the chances of finding a great teacher in a program for career changers is really high. I've hired tons of my students, and will continue to do so.

## Can agile be used in teaching/learning?

Absolutely! My education teams work in day-long iterations, we plan each morning and retro each afternoon, we collect lots of data, and only do the highest priority things.

I have been hesitating to dip my foot in here, but ...

I'm afraid of ageism. I'm turning 52 this year (and yes, I shaved by beard, which had a bunch of gray in it). I'm a far better programmer than I would be a manager.

I have felt the "ageism" of startups wanting young coworkers. I've felt it when start-ups think that hiring a young bootcamp grad for $80k/year would be able to contribute to my level _ever_, much less in the next few years. I've felt it when a CTO who hired me _almost didn't_ because he was afraid he couldn't manage someone with more experience than him. (And that was in my early 40s.) I've felt it even in Denver-area jobs that requested insane amounts of "at home" work to prove your skill -- something that a younger or unemployed developer might have time to do, but something that an older or _under-_employed developer wouldn't be able to complete.

*But.* Demand for strong senior developers is high, and enough companies _don't_ fall into those traps that I haven't really had a hard time getting a job.

So does ageism exist? Absolutely. Does it exist to the point where a really strong developer (a really strong _male_ developer, at least) can't get a job? If so, I haven't hit that point yet.

I don't have first hand experience but I did have a conversation with a co-worker on the topic a few years ago. He used to work at a medical records company that had access to millions of people's PII data (including social security numbers). The company had very strict monitoring and access control. So if one of their employees decided to look up information for say a celebrity for example... the employees' patterns of access would be flagged as unusual/suspicious pattern (based on timing and access history of retrieving those kind of records) and an internal alert would go off. He said he knew at least one employee who got found out and fired. I hear theres a lot of development going on for AI driven event detection for these kinds of security threats and privacy breaches. Lets hope Facebook are on top of it!

I had some issues with the graphql plugin due to self developed plugins. The graphql plugin trows an error 'Cannot find the controller's action'. I had some look at the root cause and think the implementation in line 150 in <https://github.com/strapi/strapi/blob/master/packages/strapi-plugin-graphql/services/Query.js> is buggy:
```        const controllers = plugin
        ? strapi.plugins[plugin].controllers
        : strapi.controllers;

      // Try to find the controller that should be related to this model.
      const controller = isSingular
        ? _.get(controllers, `${name}.findOne`)
        : _.get(controllers, `${name}.find`);```
 I changed it to
```      const controllers = plugin
        ? strapi.query(name, plugin)
        : strapi.query(name);

      // Try to find the controller that should be related to this model.
      const controller = isSingular
        ? _.get(controllers, 'findOne')
        : _.get(controllers, 'find');```
and it works

Running zookeeper is not ideal but its going away <https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/KIP-500%3A+Replace+ZooKeeper+with+a+Self-Managed+Metadata+Quorum>

AWS have a managed kafka service too but confluent are the experts.

Hi Mila,

It would basically depend on which mode your organisation is running in i.e. start-up or regularly paced (an established org.)

Candidate 1 will take up loads of time in being mentored not only in design guidelines aspect but even learning industry norms such as following brand guidelines. Here you'll need to invest your time on regular basis and can expect surprises along the way.

Candidate 2, will generally understand your expectations and will try and deliver within the scope outlined by you. The work may not spring many surprises and will be completed within set timeline.

Also, you'll need to align these candidates with senior designer you are hiring down the line.

Hope this helps in decision making process.
